title: Synthetic Recap
body:
TORONTO (AP) — The record book will show that the Toronto Raptors defeated the Charlotte Hornets, 92-88, in a gritty 1997 contest. But the final score is a mere footnote to the historic, single-handed demolition authored by Raptors guard Damon Stoudamire.

In a performance for the ages, Stoudamire was simply unstoppable, pouring in a jaw-dropping 42 points to will his team to victory. The Raptors’ offense ran through “Mighty Mouse” from the opening tip, and he delivered with a breathtaking display of scoring from every conceivable angle, leaving the Hornets grasping at air all night.

While Stoudamire’s offensive fireworks provided the fire, Raptors center Marcus Camby provided the steel. Camby dominated the glass with a monstrous 20 rebounds and protected the rim with 5 ferocious blocks, anchoring the defense whenever Charlotte threatened to close the gap. His defensive presence was the perfect counterbalance to Stoudamire’s offensive onslaught.

The Hornets, despite the heroic efforts of Glen Rice who scored 25 points, simply had no answer for the Raptors’ dynamic duo. Every Charlotte run was met with a cold-blooded jumper from Stoudamire or a momentum-shifting rejection from Camby.

In the end, this was not merely a win. It was a coronation. On this night, Damon Stoudamire etched his name into the franchise’s early lore with a legendary 42-point masterpiece, a one-man show that a resilient Charlotte squad simply could not overcome. The Raptors didn’t just win the game; they witnessed history.
